The project will facilitate the school's modern languages co-ordinator to attend an LFEE immersion course in Spanish.  The course will provide opportunities for the participant to extend their knowledge of Spanish language, the Spanish culture and relevant teaching methods that can promote the acquisition of a third language by our pupils.  

In line with Scottish government's national policy, the school is committed to developing its curriculum to provide opportunities for all pupils to be proficient in 1+2 language by the time of their transfer to secondary school.  At present, the school strives to provide opportunities for all pupils to learn French as a second language from Primaries 1 to 7.  Currently, none of the staff members are confident or trained in the delivery of Spanish.  Attendance at the course would allow the school's language coordinator to acquire the essential skills and knowledge to facilitate the training and development of all teaching staff within our two schools.

The delivery of Spanish is a future priority within our School Improvement Plan and an Action Plan will be generated by the Headteacher and school's Language Coordinator.  Part of this work will involve establishing a progressive programme of skills that takes account of the children's ongoing cross-curricular experiences.

An evaluation of the Action Plan and the learning and teaching experiences will take place, using formal and informal monitoring procedures.  The views of staff and children will be gathered to further shape the program of experiences that we provide in the teaching of 1+2 languages to ensure effectiveness and that we are meeting the needs of all our learners.  
Our approach and attitude to language learning is inclusive and ambitious for our learners.

Core forest sites - Woodland Habitat Restoration : Core sites for a forest habitat network

Scotland hosts a range of UK woodland types including several that are protected by the EU Habitats Directive. A number of these are under threat from problems associated with invasive species, over-grazing and land ownership issues. Such nature conservation concerns can fragment habitat integrity and adversely affect the functionality of woodland ecosystems.
ENERGY EFFICIENCY FOR EU HISTORIC DISTRICTS SUSTAINABILITY

Europe can become the leader in CO2 emission reduction by applying innovative solutions to its built cultural heritage. According to the European Recovery Plan one of the actions that needs to be taken to tackle the current crisis, is investing in energy efficiency. Historic urban buildings consume 4% of all energy and are responsible for 3% of CO2 emissions. Therefore, improving energy efficiency in historic buildings and historic districts is essential.

Nevertheless, most of the current developments in energy efficiency address new construction without dealing with the unique problems of historic structures. A number of technologies and products have been developed, however many of the solutions are not acceptable for historic structures due to the necessity of preserving integrity and authenticity.

Therefore, the main goal of EFFESUS is to develop and demonstrate, through case studies a methodology for assessing and selecting energy efficiency interventions, based on existing and new technologies that are compatible with heritage values.  A Decision Support System will be a primary deliverable. The environment in historic buildings and urban districts is controlled differently from modern cities and accordingly the project will also develop a multi-scale data model for the management of energy. In addition, new non-invasive, reversible yet cost-effective technologies for significantly improving thermal properties will also be developed. Finally, existing regulations and building policies may not fit cultural heritage specificities so the EFFESUS project will also address these non-technical barriers.

These outcomes will be achieved through 10 work packages, performed by an interdisciplinary consortium of 23 partners from 13 countries. Due to the attractiveness of this niche market, 36 % of the project budget is allocated to SME’s, which will work together with large companies, research institutions and end users throughout the duration of the project.

This application is for 8 Primary teachers (including the 1+2 Languages Leader) to take part in either a French or Spanish immersion course to increase language capacity and improve conversational language to A1 Level in the Common European Framework, in line with Scottish Government’s 1+2 Languages Approach. We feel that we have made a very good start to embedding modern language learning in our school and with an increase in general staff confidence, we can ensure further immersion across our curriculum.
The participants named in this application have varying requirements and objectives for attending a course in France or Spain. We are all in agreement that by visiting these countries and being fully immersed in a programme of study in French or Spanish and experiencing the culture first hand, would be a most valuable and memorable way of inspiring our learners  in the classroom. The other members of staff in Melrose Primary School will also benefit from their experiences and be inspired to engage more fully with language learning. This will have a positive impact on our children across the school as their enthusiasm for, and progress in modern language learning increases. The probationers will be able to disseminate their skills in other Scottish schools.
The immersion programme fully embraces the key principles of Curriculum for Excellence and so the experiences and knowledge gained by our participants will ensure that our French and Spanish learning programmes will reflect the seven principles of curriculum design. Teachers who have previously attended a course found the materials provided were relevant, accessible and easily utilised.  Consequently pupil engagement, enjoyment and enthusiasm for modern language learning has significantly increased. 
Through native speakers leading these courses, cultural awareness and new ways of teaching modern languages through a variety of media are experienced, in particular through ICT. All participants receive a pen drive which contains the course contents including resources and ideas for exciting and engaging learning activities. These courses also offer invaluable training in the teaching of modern languages to young learners through observing and participating in modelled activities. Another incentive of attending a course is the opportunity to network with colleagues from across Scotland, England and Ireland as well as the host country. From this, as some of our staff have already experienced, there will then be further opportunities to share resources and good practice as 1+2 continues to be developed across Scotland.

This project will consist of two parallel developments within Melrose Primary School and across Scottish Borders Council. 
The application is for 4 primary teachers from Melrose Primary School to take part in immersion courses to build on the work of the school over the last 3 years to embed and integrate the teaching of French from Primary One and to develop the school's capacity further by training teachers to begin integrating Spanish in addition to this in the Upper Primary stages. In addition to this the application includes 2 regional Development Officers, with primary and secondary backgrounds,  to take part in Immersion experiences to support developing similar models for training teachers across the Scottish Borders. 
The course activities will include speaking in the target language with native speakers, cross curricular approaches to teaching languages, developing cultural awareness of the countries in which the language is spoken and using ICT to support engaging teaching methods. The selected courses also offer in depth support and training in the teaching of European languages to young learners. Language skills developed will be French and Spanish and used to implement the national, local and school plans to address the Languages 1+2 recommendations from the Scottish Government. 
It is anticipated that the results of this project will improve staff ability and confidence in the teaching of French and Spanish, enhance the learning experience of pupils involved in learning languages, ensuring learners access languages from an earlier stage in their primary schooling and develop capacity in the use of ICT to support linguistic development. The increased skill set of the two development officers will ensure that local opportunities for career long professional learning  is offered to other teachers/schools in the area of language development. 
Ultimately the longer term benefits will be for learners to raise their attainment in languages, increase the uptake of languages at formally assessed levels in the Scottish Borders and to ensure that Scottish Borders young people are able to access the best opportunities for movement within and across Europe in the future.
